paper_title.en: Neutral rains at Athens, Greece: a natural safeguard against acidification of rains

paper_title.ja: 天然ガスの微生物分解ガスと低温熱分解ガスの境界ー軽炭化水素組成からのアプローチ
paper_title.en: A boundary between microbial gas and meta-thermogenic gas based on light hydrocarbon composition of natural gas.

description.ja: Chemical compositions of methane (C<sub>1</sub>), ethane (C<sub>2</sub>), and propane (C<sub>3</sub>) of natural gases from their production wells in Japan were measured for clarifying mechanisms of their generations in combination with δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values. Natural gases having δ<sup>13</sup>Cc1 values of -70‰ to -62‰ give extremely high C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios of 1, 000 to 6, 900 and little C<sub>2</sub> and C<sub>3</sub> contents (lower than 0.1% and 0.05%, respectively), indicating that they are generated by microbial decomposition of organic matter in the formations. As δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values of natural gases increase from -60‰ to -50‰, their C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios decrease sharply from about 1, 000 up to 2, because of extreme increases of C<sub>2</sub> and C<sub>3</sub> contents up to about 10%. Furthermore, as their δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values increase from -40‰ to -30‰, their C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios increase again, showing that natural gases having δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values from -50‰to -40‰ give the lowest C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios. These results indicate the existence of metathermogenic gas proposed as an intermediate between microbial and thermogenic gases by Kita et al. (2001) and support their proposal that -40‰ of δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> value can be defined as the boundary between meta-thermogenic gas (MTG) and thermogenic gas (TG) based on the relationship between δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values and N2/Ar ratios. Furthermore, the sharp decrease of C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios in the range of δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value from -60‰ to -50‰ indicates that -60‰ of δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value can be used as the boundary between microbial gas (MG) and meta-thermogenic gas (MTG). On the other hand, the relationship between C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios and δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> values of natural gases is similar to that between their C<sub>1</sub>/C<sub>2</sub> ratios and δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> values. This indicates that C<sub>1</sub>/C<sub>2</sub> ratio can be used instead of C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratio for discussing their origins in combination with δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value.
description.en: Chemical compositions of methane (C<sub>1</sub>), ethane (C<sub>2</sub>), and propane (C<sub>3</sub>) of natural gases from their production wells in Japan were measured for clarifying mechanisms of their generations in combination with δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values. Natural gases having δ<sup>13</sup>Cc1 values of -70‰ to -62‰ give extremely high C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios of 1, 000 to 6, 900 and little C<sub>2</sub> and C<sub>3</sub> contents (lower than 0.1% and 0.05%, respectively), indicating that they are generated by microbial decomposition of organic matter in the formations. As δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values of natural gases increase from -60‰ to -50‰, their C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios decrease sharply from about 1, 000 up to 2, because of extreme increases of C<sub>2</sub> and C<sub>3</sub> contents up to about 10%. Furthermore, as their δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values increase from -40‰ to -30‰, their C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios increase again, showing that natural gases having δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values from -50‰to -40‰ give the lowest C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios. These results indicate the existence of metathermogenic gas proposed as an intermediate between microbial and thermogenic gases by Kita et al. (2001) and support their proposal that -40‰ of δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> value can be defined as the boundary between meta-thermogenic gas (MTG) and thermogenic gas (TG) based on the relationship between δ<sup>13</sup>Cc<sub>1</sub> values and N2/Ar ratios. Furthermore, the sharp decrease of C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios in the range of δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value from -60‰ to -50‰ indicates that -60‰ of δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value can be used as the boundary between microbial gas (MG) and meta-thermogenic gas (MTG). On the other hand, the relationship between C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratios and δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> values of natural gases is similar to that between their C<sub>1</sub>/C<sub>2</sub> ratios and δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> values. This indicates that C<sub>1</sub>/C<sub>2</sub> ratio can be used instead of C<sub>1</sub>/(C<sub>2</sub>+C<sub>3</sub>) ratio for discussing their origins in combination with δ13Cc<sub>1</sub> value.

paper_title.ja: 天然ガスの微生物分解ガスと低温熱分解ガスの境界―軽炭化水素組成からのアプローチ―:軽炭化水素組成からのアプローチ

paper_title.ja: CH<sub>4</sub>の炭素同位体比とN<sub>2</sub>/Ar比の分布に基づく天然ガスの生成プロセス
paper_title.en: Generation process of natural gases based on carbon isotopic ratios of CH4 and N2/Ar ratios.

description.ja: Carbon isotopic ratios, δ<sup>13</sup>C values, of CH<sub>4</sub> gases from their production wells in Japan were measured for discussing the generation process of natural gases in formations, based on the positive correlation between their N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios reported by Kita et al. (1999). Their δ<sup>13</sup>C values are distributed in a range of about-70‰ to-30‰, covering those of CH<sub>4</sub> gases generated by bacterial and thermal decompositions of organic matter in formations. We found a clear relation between δ<sup>13</sup>C values of CH<sub>4</sub> and N<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratios as well as between those of CH<sub>4</sub> and He/Ar ratios, supporting that the correlation between N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios of natural gases reflects the decomposition process of organic matter in formation. Furthermore, the N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios increase gradually in the range of δ<sup>13</sup>C values from-70‰ to-40‰ and start to increase drastically at about-40‰. This seems to give a first criterion for defining thermogenic CH<sub>4</sub> gases as those higher than-40‰. These relations between δ<sup>13</sup>C value of CH<sub>4</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratio, and He/Ar ratio of natural gases can play an important role in clarifying the chemical and geological environments of their generations and accumulations in formations.
description.en: Carbon isotopic ratios, δ<sup>13</sup>C values, of CH<sub>4</sub> gases from their production wells in Japan were measured for discussing the generation process of natural gases in formations, based on the positive correlation between their N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios reported by Kita et al. (1999). Their δ<sup>13</sup>C values are distributed in a range of about-70‰ to-30‰, covering those of CH<sub>4</sub> gases generated by bacterial and thermal decompositions of organic matter in formations. We found a clear relation between δ<sup>13</sup>C values of CH<sub>4</sub> and N<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratios as well as between those of CH<sub>4</sub> and He/Ar ratios, supporting that the correlation between N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios of natural gases reflects the decomposition process of organic matter in formation. Furthermore, the N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios increase gradually in the range of δ<sup>13</sup>C values from-70‰ to-40‰ and start to increase drastically at about-40‰. This seems to give a first criterion for defining thermogenic CH<sub>4</sub> gases as those higher than-40‰. These relations between δ<sup>13</sup>C value of CH<sub>4</sub>, N<sub>2</sub>/Ar ratio, and He/Ar ratio of natural gases can play an important role in clarifying the chemical and geological environments of their generations and accumulations in formations.

paper_title.en: Origins of Natural gases and environment of their generation has, based on N<sub>2</sub>/Ar and He/Ar ratios

publication_name.en: Journal of the Japanese Association for Petroleum Technology

paper_title.ja: 深部地層中のHeの移動現象と天然ガスの起源
paper_title.en: Migration of He gases and origin of CH4 gases in deep formations from exploration and production wells of oil and natural gas.

description.ja:
He isotopic ratios of gas samples from exploration and production wells of oils and natural gases in the northeast Japan were measured for discussing the migration of He gas between the formations in the Green Tuff region. In Niigata and Akita Prefectures, He gases from the Green Tuff formations give the highest 3He/4He ratios, indicating magmatic origins. It is noted that both radiogenic and magmatic He gases were found from the different depths of the same formation in Niigata Prefecture. This feature strongly indicates that the magmatic He is not originated from volcanic rock, although volcanic rocks homogeneously distributes in the formation. In Akita Prefecture, He gases in the formation containing little volcanic rocks have the large proportion of magmatic He. Therefore, it can be inferred that magmatic He migrates from the Green Tuff formation to upper formations through faults or cracks.
δ13C value of CH4 gas coexisting with radiogenic He found in the Niigata Green Tuff region was -28.1‰, indicating the thermogenic origin. The same feature was observed in the natural gases from the Iwaki-oki production wells located in the Pacific ocean. In contrast, in the Akita area, He and CH4 gases from the formation containing little volcanic rocks give magmatic 3He/4He ratios and biogenic δ13C values. These gases deviate from the positive correlation between the 3He/4He ratios and δ13C values of CH4 which have been reported for natural gases from Japanese island arcs. Therefore, the relation demonstrated previously has no meaning for discussing the origin of CH4 in natural gases. These results seem to support that the origins of CH4 having high δ13C values from the Green Tuff region in Japan are mainly not magmatic but thermogenic.
description.en:
He isotopic ratios of gas samples from exploration and production wells of oils and natural gases in the northeast Japan were measured for discussing the migration of He gas between the formations in the Green Tuff region. In Niigata and Akita Prefectures, He gases from the Green Tuff formations give the highest 3He/4He ratios, indicating magmatic origins. It is noted that both radiogenic and magmatic He gases were found from the different depths of the same formation in Niigata Prefecture. This feature strongly indicates that the magmatic He is not originated from volcanic rock, although volcanic rocks homogeneously distributes in the formation. In Akita Prefecture, He gases in the formation containing little volcanic rocks have the large proportion of magmatic He. Therefore, it can be inferred that magmatic He migrates from the Green Tuff formation to upper formations through faults or cracks.
δ13C value of CH4 gas coexisting with radiogenic He found in the Niigata Green Tuff region was -28.1‰, indicating the thermogenic origin. The same feature was observed in the natural gases from the Iwaki-oki production wells located in the Pacific ocean. In contrast, in the Akita area, He and CH4 gases from the formation containing little volcanic rocks give magmatic 3He/4He ratios and biogenic δ13C values. These gases deviate from the positive correlation between the 3He/4He ratios and δ13C values of CH4 which have been reported for natural gases from Japanese island arcs. Therefore, the relation demonstrated previously has no meaning for discussing the origin of CH4 in natural gases. These results seem to support that the origins of CH4 having high δ13C values from the Green Tuff region in Japan are mainly not magmatic but thermogenic.

description.en:
He isotopic ratios of gas samples from exploration and production wells of oils and natural gases in the northeast Japan were measured for discussing the migration of He gas between the formations in the Green Tuff region. In Niigata and Akita Prefectures, He gases from the Green Tuff formations give the highest 3He/4He ratios, indicating magmatic origins. It is noted that both radiogenic and magmatic He gases were found from the different depths of the same formation in Niigata Prefecture. This feature strongly indicates that the magmatic He is not originated from volcanic rock, although volcanic rocks homogeneously distributes in the formation. In Akita Prefecture, He gases in the formation containing little volcanic rocks have the large proportion of magmatic He. Therefore, it can be inferred that magmatic He migrates from the Green Tuff formation to upper formations through faults or cracks.
δ13C value of CH4 gas coexisting with radiogenic He found in the Niigata Green Tuff region was -28.1‰, indicating the thermogenic origin. The same feature was observed in the natural gases from the Iwaki-oki production wells located in the Pacific ocean. In contrast, in the Akita area, He and CH4 gases from the formation containing little volcanic rocks give magmatic 3He/4He ratios and biogenic δ13C values. These gases deviate from the positive correlation between the 3He/4He ratios and δ13C values of CH4 which have been reported for natural gases from Japanese island arcs. Therefore, the relation demonstrated previously has no meaning for discussing the origin of CH4 in natural gases. These results seem to support that the origins of CH4 having high δ13C values from the Green Tuff region in Japan are mainly not magmatic but thermogenic.

paper_title.ja: CO<sub>2</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>比とCH<sub>4</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>比に基づく気体地質温度計の開発

paper_title.en: New gas geothermometers using CO2/H2 and CH4/H2 ratios

description.en:
The chemical compositions of gas samples from the steaming ground of the Komatsu Jigoku in the Kuju geothermal area, Kyushu, Japan, were measured. Using a gas geothermometer based on H2, CO2, CH4 and H2S contents (D'Amore and Panichi, 1980), the underground temperatures of the Komatsu Jigoku were calculated. From the relationships between the obtained temperatures and the CO2/H2 and CH4/H2 ratios, two gas geothermometers excluding H2S contents are developed. The equations are presented as follows, TCO2/H2(°C) = 352.45-53.36 log (CO2/H2)TCH4/H2(°C) = 228.95-24.06 (CH4/H2). These gas geothermometers were applied to gas samples from the production wells of the Hatchobaru and the Otake geothermal areas, Kyushu, Japan. The obtained temperatures (TCO2/H2 and TCH4/H2) agree with those (Tquartz) estimated by silica content in the geothermal waters within 20°C in a temperature range between 200°C and 250°C. Besides, the bubble gases from hot springs having different water temperatures (97°C and 25°C) gave reasonable temperatures (195°C to 209°C) in the Otake production area. Thus, it can be concluded that these simple gas geothermometers are useful for estimating the temperatures of geothermal systems (&lt
250°C). Furthermore, CO2/H2 geothermometer is found to be successfully applicable to the temperature beyond 250°C. On the other hand, the values of TCH4/H2 become relatively lower than those of TCO2/H2 and Tquartz above 250°C. The reason of lowering is not clear at present. Further test of the CH4/H2geothermometer at other geothermal systems is required to investigate the reason. © 1995, THE GEOTHERMAL RESEARCH SOCIETY OF JAPAN. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: O and C stable isotope geochemistry of Volcanic gases and thermal waters from the Aegean island arc
Information on Geothermal System Obtained by Chemical and Isotopic Characteristics of Soil and Fumarolic Gases from the Doroyu-Kawarage Geothermal Field, Akita, Japan

description.en: For soil gases from the Doroyu-Kawarage geothermal field in northern Japan, the concentrations of Rn, H2, CH4, CO2 and rare gases (He and Ne) together with isotopic ratios of CO2 and He (δ 13C of CO2 and 3He/4He) were measured. In presently developing geothermal field to the northern part of Doroyu fault, Rn concentrations of soil gases are clearly higher than those to the southern part. On the other hand, the distribution of low δ 13C values (-20~-24 %) corresponds to that of Sanzugawaformation.This formation contains the organic matter underlying only to the northern part of the fault. However, higher δ13C values to the northern part, coexist with high concentration of H2. Soil gas samples from Kawarage and Doroyu geothermal manifestations contain high concentrations of Rn, H2 and CO2, and the δ 13C values also are extremely high. Therefore, it is inferred that CO2 derived from a deep-seated geothermal system are added to those originated from organic matter in the Sanzugawa formation. These data indicate that the δ 13C values of CO2 can be useful in geothermal prospecting in addition to information provided by H2 measurement. Soil gases from Kawarage and the vicinity do not give the high Rn concentrations, in spite of the high Hg concentrations. Such a fact may give the information on the alteration by the secondary hydrothermal water without U and Th, which is originated from the vaporization of deep-seated geothermal water. Furthermore, the 3He/4He and 4He/20Ne ratios of Kawarage fumarolic gas are 9.5×10-6 and 180, respectively, indicating that the He is originated from magmatic gas. This fact is consistent with a consideration that the heat source of this geothermal field is the magma of the neighboring Quaternary volcanos such as Mt. Takamatsudake and Mt. Kabuto. © 1992, THE GEOTHERMAL RESEARCH SOCIETY OF JAPAN. All rights reserved.
